required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: NASHA/Dx as a Perianal Implant for the Treatment of Persistent Fecal Incontience After Anorectal Malformation
clinical_study.official_title: NASHA/Dx as a Perianal Implant for the Treatment of Persistent Fecal Incontience After Anorectal Malformation

brief_summary.textblock:
Persistent fecal incontinence (FI) after anorectal malformations (ARM) is a common occurence. During the last two decades perianal injection therapy has emerged as an option for treating patients with FI due to other causes than ARMs. The studies done on different implants have always expempted patients with ARM which has led to ARM being a formal contraindication for treatment with perianal injection therapy.
The study aims to treat patients with persistent FI after ARM with perianal injection of NASHA/Dx (Solesta®) and follow them with Clinical examination and questionnaires up to 18 months post treatment.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Patients are treated with injection of NASHA/Dx and act as their own Controls over time.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in number of incontinence episodes
primary_outcome.time_frame: The change in number of incontinence episodes before treatment is compared with data at 18 months after injection.
primary_outcome.description: The number of incontinences episodes as measured over a two week interval The number of incontience episodes is measured with a bowel-movement-diary over a two week period.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before treatment compared with data at 18 months after treatment. Miller´s incontinence score is measured on a scale from 0 (meaning total fecal continence) to 18 (meaning total fecal incontinence).

Before treatment compared with data at 18 months after treatment. SF-36 measures quality of life in 8 subscales. Each scaled from 0 to 100. Higher score is considered better. Two total scores of mental and physical QoL can be calculated.
secondary_outcome.description: Change in quality of Life as observed with SF-36

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before treatment compared with data at 18 months after treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Control of any adverse events during the course of the study

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before treatment compared with data at 18 months after treatment. Measures 4 subscales, each measuring 1-4. Higher score implies better quality of life.
secondary_outcome.description: Change in quality of Life as observed with FIQL

arm_group.description: Patients are given NASHA/Dx as a perianal injection

intervention.description: Perianal submucosal injection of 3-4 ml of NASHA/Dx

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Persistent FI (Miller incontinence score >5)
- Anorectal malformation.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Rectal prolapse
- Significant mucosal prolapse
- Inflammatory bowel disease
- Anorectal surgery within the last year Before inclusion
- Anticoagulant medication/bleeding diathesis
- Anorectal sepsis in the past
- Immunodeficiency
- Immunosuppressing therapy

results_reference.citation: Danielson J, Karlbom U, Wester T, Graf W. Efficacy and quality of life 2 years after treatment for faecal incontinence with injectable bulking agents. Tech Coloproctol. 2013 Aug;17(4):389-95. doi: 10.1007/s10151-012-0949-8. Epub 2012 Dec 7.

Danielson J, Karlbom U, Sonesson AC, Wester T, Graf W. Submucosal injection of stabilized nonanimal hyaluronic acid with dextranomer: a new treatment option for fecal incontinence. Dis Colon Rectum. 2009 Jun;52(6):1101-6. doi: 10.1007/DCR.0b013e31819f5cbf.

Danielson J, Karlbom U, Graf W, Wester T. Outcome in adults with anorectal malformations in relation to modern classification - Which patients do we need to follow beyond childhood? J Pediatr Surg. 2017 Mar;52(3):463-468. doi: 10.1016/j.jpedsurg.2016.10.051. Epub 2016 Nov 15.

patient_data.ipd_description: The data collected is of very personal type and since the number of subjects is so small there would be a risk of identification if all the data was released.
